Award.AwardTitle: ACS Symposium on Emulsions, Bubbles and Foams: Fundamentals and Applications, New Orleans, Louisiana, April 7th - 11th, 2013

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1219323
PI: Lee

Funds will be used to organize a 2013 ACS symposium titled ?Emulsions, Bubbles and Foams: Fundamentals and Applications? for the Spring American Chemical Society (ACS) Meeting in New Orleans, LA through the ACS Division of Colloid and Surface Chemistry, April 7th to 11th, 2013 and to partially support travel costs of participants. Emulsions, bubbles and foams are multiphase systems that have a broad range of applications in biomedicine, food, cosmetics, pharmaceutics, and renewable energy. The objective of the symposium is to bring together scientists and engineers studying these systems from both fundamentals and applications points of view. These systems are complex in nature; thus, development of new products based on these materials could significantly benefit from fundamental understanding and insights. The NSF support will be used towards the travel costs of participants from academia and industry. The program theme of the 245th ACS National Meeting is Chemistry of Energy and Food, making this meeting particularly well suited to host the proposed symposium.

Emulsions, bubbles and foams are multiphase systems that make up important classes of materials that are studied in academia and commercialized by industry. However, only a limited number of conferences, symposia, and workshops related to emulsions, bubbles and foams have been offered recently. Through this proposed symposium, the global emulsion and bubble/foam communities will have a unique opportunity to interact. Participants in all stages of their career and of diverse backgrounds, especially those from academia and industry, will be encouraged to participate by offering partial financial support.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major objective of the symposium which was held during the 2013 Spring National American Chemical Society Meeting in New Orleans was to intersect the fields of emulsions and bubbles/foams and also to bring together scientists and engineers in basic and applied fields. Emulsions, bubbles and foams are multiphasic systems that have a broad range of applications in biomedicine, food, cosmetics, pharmaceutics and, more recently, renewable energy. We felt that there was a disconnect in this field between the basic and appliedsciences, owing in part to the two groups attending different sets of meetings. The goal of the proposed symposium thus was to provide a forum where experts and novices from both the applied and basic sciences can interact, focused on the topic areas of emulsions, bubbles and foams.We have successfully accomplished our goals by organizing highly multidisplinary sessions that brough together researchers from diverse areas. We invited 12 invited speakers who gave presentations on a wide range of topics from the mreasurement of colloidal forces between bubbles to the use of microbubbles for ultrasound imaging to the application of silicone emulsions in industry.  In total, 8 sessions were organized including a tutorial session.  Session topics include particle-stabilized emulsions and bubbles, microbubble fundamentals, microfluidics, biomedical applications, fundamentals, emulsion and bubble-templated materials, and fundamentals (II).  These sessions brought together scientists and engineers that do not necessarily interact with each other on regular basis.  For example, Dr. Shelley Anna who is well known for her work on complex fluids interacted actively with those in microbubble enhanced ultrasound imaging. Also each session had a mix of invited presentations by renowned researchers and contributed talks by students and postdocs allowing for interaction between senior and junior members of the community. In total, 65 presentations (64 oral and 1 poster) were given during the symposium.  These presentataions included topics from fundamentals of emulsions and foams to their applications in biomedicine.  The sessions were very well attended (consistently over 30 people in the audience).  The abstract submitted to our symposium are available on-line on the ACS website.  Our symposium was also selected as a C&EN Pick (http://vimeo.com/60788082) and was featured on monitors throughout the conference.  NSF support was critical in supporting junior faculty members as well as those from under-represented minority groups to participate in this highly multidisciplinary and interactive symposium.
